posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: I’ve recently hopped on the Rust bandwagon, and really want to replace Java with Rust on my team.  I know that’s a bad idea for a variety of reasons (the language is too hard, there’s not enough support, etc.), but is it possible ?  Would we have to rewrite WPILib and Vendor libraries from scratch, or is there a way to reuse the existing APIs on some level?  Has anyone else tried this recently?  I’ve seen a few projects along these lines from 5+ years ago, but they seem to have fizzled out. Interested to see all your thoughts.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
I’m very much not a rust dev, but this sounds like an uphill battle.

That said, I’d assume the best path forward would be to link against the C++ libraries for WPILib (assuming thats even possoble in rust)

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
Paraduks:

Has anyone else tried this recently?

first-rust-competition goes back to April 2018, but it hasn’t been maintained in 2 years. It also doesn’t seem to provide wpimath wrappers (so no physics sim, pose estimators, feedback controllers, etc.).

In general, your options are either wrap the C++ API like Python does (probably won’t facilitate an idiomatic Rust API), or rewrite it all in Rust. The latter is impossible to maintain as a thirdparty project because the main library changes too fast.

When RobotPy became official recently, we essentially just added Python specifics to docs.wpilib.org and let the RobotPy team continue to do its usual wrapper update and release process.

I’d personally like the RobotPy wrappers to be more tightly integrated with the allwpilib monorepo and require Java/C++ PR authors to also update the Python wrapper for CI to pass. This would have two benefits:

Eliminate the large change backlog RobotPy developers must process right before beta/kickoff.

Allow manual, incremental API improvements toward something more Pythonic, rather than relying on the currently unidiomatic automated output.

For those same reasons, I’d also be in favor of a Rust wrapper maintained in the monorepo.

posts.name: Wilson Watson
posts.cooked:
In general, its difficult to wrap C++ codebases with Rust, given that Rust’s FFI only supports the C ABI. Certain libraries like cxx make this easier, but it is by no means automatic, and requires the maintainers to define effectively C-with-some-rust-classes functions for every FFI call. autocxx tries to make this more automated, but I’ve had limited success using it in the past.

However, there does exist a C interface at a lower level, since Java’s Native Interface (JNI) uses the C ABI to handle native calls. Wrapping those might be less of a headache, and provide enough room between wpilib and the user-facing code to allow for a more idiomatic API. Some barriers to this implementation would be:

c-variadics are still in nightly . There are some crates that define va_list , but they only support a limited set of architectures.

Some JNIEnv functions like DefineClass would be difficult to implement (though a quick perusal through allwpilib show no usage of such functions).

On the Rust side, we’d need to handle all classes, methods, and fields the JNI methods would try to interact with.

link_counts.title: Rust ❤️ pre-existing C++ - Rust ♡ Existing C++
Tracking issue for RFC 2137: Support defining C-compatible variadic functions in Rust · Issue #44930 · rust-lang/rust · GitHub

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked: i dont know TOO much about rust, but wouldnt linking against the cpp libraries remove the usefulness of a programming language like rust?

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
No, because Rust library code calling unsafe C++ code doesn’t negate the safety checks done on Rust user code. unsafe exists to compartmentalize the code you have to manually audit for safety. Rust’s borrow checker also still runs on unsafe Rust code; unsafe just lets you do the following things:

Dereference a raw pointer

Call an unsafe function or method

Access or modify a mutable static variable

Implement an unsafe trait

Access fields of a union

link_counts.title: Unsafe Rust - The Rust Programming Language

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: Photon is hopefully finally jumping onboard the python-in-monorepo train for 2025. C++/python bind tools like nanobind and pybind just require developers copy paste some “.def”’s a handful of times for new functions they add. It’s annoying for new contributors who just wanna add one function quickly and now need to set up some extra tools on their machine to test outside of CI, but keeping everything in one place is great for driving down iteration cycle time.
